description: Noun dated in the 13th century AD and verb dated in the late 14th century AD; from claspe, possible modification of clapse, which is from Old English clyppan (“to grasp”). Related to English enclasp (“embrace, hold tightly in one's arms”).

nouns.description: Noun dated in the 13th century AD and verb dated in the late 14th century AD; from claspe, possible modification of clapse, which is from Old English clyppan (“to grasp”). Related to English enclasp (“embrace, hold tightly in one's arms”).

entries.meaning: A fastener or holder, particularly one that clasps.
examples: I always have a hard time working the clasp on this necklace!

entries.meaning: (in the singular) An embrace, a grasp, or handshake.
examples: He took her hand in a firm clasp.

verbs.description: clasp (third-person singular simple present clasps, present participle clasping, simple past and past participle clasped)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To take hold of; to grasp.
examples: They clasped hands and parted as friends.

entries.meaning: To shut or fasten together with, or as if with, a clasp.
